module.title: Emergency Neurological Life Support
module.comments: This is the first version of ENLS

node.title: Step 1
node.explanation:
Out of hospital:
  • Acute onset focal neurologic symptoms
  • 911 EMS services alerted

node.title: Imaging does not show hemorrhage
node.body: CT or MRI imaging are either normal, or show an ischemic infarct
node.explanation:
CT or MRI imaging is either normal, or shows an ischemic infarct.
Click here to open the Ischemic Stroke Protocol

node.title: Imaging Shows Hemorrhage
node.body: CT or MR imaging show a hemorrhage
node.explanation: CT or MRI imaging reveal hemorrhage in the brain accounting for their neurological findings. Now determine whether the blood is in the subarachnoid space or within the brain itself (including ventricle).

node.title: Step 4
node.explanation:
Imaging:
  • CT or MRI - CT is usually faster
  • Consider "Stroke CT" that includes non-contrast head CT, CTA (angiography) of the neck and brain, and CT perfusion of the brain
  • Consider MRI that includes MRA of head and neck, DWI and MR perfusion of the brain

    • Note: imaging inclusions and exclusions regarding t-PA administration are typically based on a non-contrast CT of the head alone.

node.title: Step 3
node.explanation:
Emergency department evaluation:
  • ABCs
  • Focused neurologic exam (5 minutes): GCS, NIHSS
  • History: medications, atrial fibrillation
  • Labs: CBC, PT/PTT, glucose, chemistry panel

node.title: Step 2
node.explanation:
Prehospital Evaluation:
  • ABCs
  • Stroke screening tool
  • Time last known normal
  • Medication list
  • Consider triage to stroke center

node.title: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
node.body: Most of the blood is within the brain parenchyma
node.explanation:
If there was clear evidence of head trauma, the blood may be simply due to the trauma alone. If so, Click here to open the Traumatic Brain Injury Protocol
If there is no evidence of head trauma, Click here to open the Intracerebral Hemorrhage Protocol

node.title: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
node.body: CT or MRI shows blood in the subarachnoid space
node.explanation:
The predominance of blood is in the subarachnoid space. If there was clear evidence of head trauma, the blood may be simply due to the trauma alone. If so, Click here to open the Traumatic Brain Injury Protocol
If the predominance of blood in in the subarachnoid space and there is no evidence of head trauma, the hemorrhage is likely due to a ruptured cerebral aneurysm. Click here to open the Subarachnoid Hemorrhage Protocol

content.li: Imaging findings: primary hemorrhage, ischemia, or normal scan

list.li: Establish time of onset (time last seen normal)
Labs: CBC, Platelets, Chemistries, PT/PTT, glucose
